Knowledge Point: The personal pronouns may be modified by the intensive pronouns mèz `myself', etc. The paradigm is as follows: mèz, -a, tèz, -a, sèz, -a, nus sèzs, -as, vus sèzs, -as, sèzs, -as; however, there is a general tendency in Sursilvan varieties to use sèz for all persons, a development which parallels the case of \isi{reflexive} sa- which is used for all persons in all tenses and moods (see \sectref{sec:4.1} and \sectref{sec:5.5.1}). In the corpus, there are only examples for mèz `myself' and sèz `herself, himself'. These may be used attributively (\ref{ex:jumeza}) or predicatively \ref{ex:meza}).

Knowledge Point: Determiners precede adjectives and nouns. The modifying \isi{noun phrases}, \isi{prepositional phrases}, and \isi{relative clauses} follow the \isi{noun}. Adjectives precede or follow the \isi{noun}; intensifiers precede the \isi{adjective}. If combinations of determiners occur, the \isi{demonstrative} precedes the \isi{possessive} which in turn precedes the \isi{numeral}: quèls nòs ufauns `these our children' -- but these combinations are rare. The only combination of determiners occurring in the corpus is a \isi{possessive} with a \isi{numeral} (\ref{ex:possnum}).
